Table 1 Catalysts Theoretical loading Ni:Fe (molar ratio) Experimental loading Ni:Fe (molar ratio) Particle size (nm) CO uptake (μmol/g) Ni (wt%) Fe (wt%) Ni (wt%) Fe (wt%) Ni/TiO2 2.5 – 1:0 1.88 – 1:0 3.92 6.7 Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2 2.5 0.12 1:0.05 1.60 0.13 1:0.08 3.88 6.2 Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2 2.5 0.25 1:0.1 1.82 0.24 1:0.13 4.48 6.0 Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 2.5 0.5 1:0.2 1.82 0.49 1:0.26 5.56 2.8 Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 2.5 0.82 1:0.33 2.13 0.75 1:0.35 6.32 1.8 Fe/TiO2 – 2.5 0:1 – 2.32 0:1 – 1.0 Alloying effect enhanced bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts for selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene in the presence of an excess of propylene Wei-Hao Wang a † Bo Jiang a † Zhao Wang a ⁎ Ya Chen a Yao Li a Ting-Ting Luo b Feng Cheng a Bao-Lian Su a c a The State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Material Synthesis and processing, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, China The State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Material Synthesis and processing Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan 430070 China aThe State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Material Synthesis and processing, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, China b Center for Materials Research and Analysis, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, China Center for Materials Research and Analysis Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan 430070 China bCenter for Materials Research and Analysis, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, China c Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry (CMI), University of Namur, 61 Rue de Bruxelles, B-5000 Namur, Belgium Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry (CMI) University of Namur 61 Rue de Bruxelles Namur B-5000 Belgium cLaboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry (CMI), University of Namur, 61 Rue de Bruxelles, B-5000 Namur, Belgium ⁎ Corresponding author. † These authors contributed equally. Nickel is a promising Pd alternative candidate for selective alkynes/alkadienes hydrogenation owing to its high catalytic activity and cheap price, however, with fatal restrictions of low alkenes selectivity and inferior stability caused by its strong olefin adsorption and the cleavage of carbon-carbon bond. Herein, controlled amounts of iron were introduced into nickel as catalytic assistant by deposition-precipitation with urea on TiO2 support. Using 1,3-butadiene in an excess of propylene to simulate the industrial process, the additional Fe shows a significant enhancement to the catalytic performance of Ni, i.e., Ni-Fe/TiO2 with Ni/Fe atomic ratio 1:0.33 shows >94% of 1,3-butadiene conversion and >95% of alkenes selectivity after above 200 h of time on stream, superior to that of commercial Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. Further in-situ analysis reveals that the alloying effect from the formation of Ni-rich Ni-Fe intermetallic compound (e.g., Ni3Fe alloy) enlarges the distance between two Ni active sites and enriches the electronic density of Ni sites, resulting in a weak adsorption of butenes products for offering such excellent catalytic performance. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first in-depth exploration on supported Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrogenation of light alkynes/alkadienes. It shows a high potential for replacing the commercial Pd-based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Bimetallic catalysts Butadiene Ni-Fe/TiO2 Ni3Fe alloy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Light alkenes are basic feedstocks in the current chemical industry for the synthesis of plastic films, rubber and other products by catalytic polymerization reaction over Ziegler-Natta catalysts [1]. These light alkenes are mainly obtained from the catalytic cracking of naphtha [2], normally with the presence of alkynes and alkadienes as impurities. For example, ethylene contains 0.5% ∼ 3.0% of acetylene impurity; propylene contains 2.0% ∼ 8.0% of propyne and propadiene impurities and butenes contain 0.3% ∼ 6.0% of butyne and butadiene impurities [3]. Fatally, these impurities not only affect the polymerization reaction of mono-olefins and reduces the quality of polymer products, but also poison the Ziegler-Natta catalysts for polymerization reaction [4]. These alkynes and alkadienes impurities in alkenes feedstocks have to be eliminated to a concentration below 5 ppm [2,5,6]. Selective hydrogenation is one of the most economical and efficient methods for impurities purification. It selectively converts alkynes and alkadienes impurities in the presence of an excess of alkenes to alkenes feedstocks by semi-hydrogenation reaction, avoiding a full-hydrogenation to alkanes. Therefore, high catalytic activity and superior alkenes selectivity, as well as long-term stability are strongly required for the catalysts employed in industrial selective hydrogenation reaction [7]. Currently, supported palladium-based catalysts are the commercial choices in industry owing to the high catalytic activity of Pd as the low energy barrier (∼ 0 eV) for hydrogen dissociation on Pd [8]. L. Piccolo et al. [9] found that 0.15 wt% of Pd/Al2O3 shows 100% of butadiene conversion at 68 °C. However, the butenes selectivity of supported Pd dramatically decrease from 75% to below 30% with an increase of butadiene conversion from 60% to 100% as the rapid H2 dissociation causes a H-rich surface of Pd for over-hydrogenation reaction [10]. Introducing catalytic assistant is a wildly accepted strategy to obtain an enhanced catalytic performance [11]. Various Pd-based bimetallic catalysts have been extensively explored, including Pd-Ag [12–14], Pd-Au [15–17], Pd-Cu [18,19], Pd-Zn [20,21] and etc. [22,23], with an informative review summarized by A. Dhakshinamoorthy et al. in 2022 [24]. Specially, supported Pd-Ag catalyst received a widespread interest owing to its high catalytic selectivity to alkenes. For example, H.L. Huang. [25] developed Pd-Ag/eggshell (ES) catalyst for selective hydrogenation of butadiene. It was found that the bimetallic Pd4Ag1/ES catalyst shows 95.8% of butenes selectivity at above 95% of butadiene conversion over 30 h of catalytic reaction. Further exploration reveals that the addition of Ag could alter the type of alkenes adsorption from the di-σ-bonded mode to the π-bonded mode by forming Pd-Ag nanoalloys [26]. Recently, the development of new Pd based catalysts (e.g., BASF NanoSelect™ catalysts) prepared using colloidal deposition methods allows to achieve higher performances than classical Lindlar's catalysts in selective hydrogenation reactions [27]. However, even though palladium-based catalysts are wildly used in industry [11,28], the high cost of Pd (>2000 dollars per kilogram [29]) strongly calls for innovations on the cheap catalysts, specially supported non-noble metallic catalysts. Nickel is one of the most promising candidates for palladium alternative owing to its high catalytic activity as well as relatively low price of 27.5 dollars per kilogram, which is hundred times cheaper than that of Pd [2,30,31]. A. Aguilar-Tapia et al. [32] found that Ni/TiO2 catalyst (0.28 wt%) for selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene in the presence of an excess of propylene shows 100% of butadiene conversion temperature at 30 °C, unfortunately, with ethylene selectivity below 52%. Obviously, monometallic Ni catalysts have serious problem in alkenes selectivity, especially at high alkynes/alkadienes conversion (e.g., ∼100%). Recent studies revealed that the mainly reasons are the strong olefin coordination ability and high olefin activation ability of Ni active site [3,33,34]. In order to obtain an improved catalytic performance, Ni-based bimetallic catalysts were also intensively explored by researchers [35,36]. For example, M.W. Song et al. [37] have proposed Ni-K/Al2O3 catalyst by using the incipient wetness impregnation method, fixing Ni loading at 15 wt%, with various K loadings. They obtained an enhanced butene selectivity of 50% with 80% butadiene conversion for NiK0.4/Al2O3, and it is 16% higher than that of mono-metal Ni catalyst. However, inferior catalytic stability (i.e., <8 h) was observed. Furthermore, Y.Q. Cao et al. [38] explored Ni-Ga/layered double hydroxides (LDHs) catalyst by a co-precipitation method. With Ni loading of 10 wt%, they found that the catalyst with Ga/Ni molar ratios 0.6 (Ni5Ga3/LDHs) shows 82% of selectivity to ethylene at 100% acetylene conversion under 120 °C, it is much higher than that of mono-metal Ni catalysts with 48% of selectivity to ethylene at 100% acetylene conversion under 120 °C. Even though the stability of Ni-based catalyst (e.g., Ni5Ga3/LDHs) was extended to above 24 h, it is still much lower than that for industrial application (e.g., above 200 h in laboratory). Therefore, it indicates that further exploration on the alternative nickel-based catalysts with high catalytic activity, superior alkenes selectivity and long-term stability is a pressing and challenging demand. Iron could be an attractive assistant for optimizing the catalytic performance of nickel as its abundant reserves in earth [35]. To the best of our knowledge, rare attention has been paid on the exploration of supported bimetallic Fe-Ni for selective hydrogenation of light alkynes/alkadienes. However, the promotional effect of Fe assistant on the catalytic hydrogenation performance of Ni was studied in other chemical compounds, including nitroarenes, guaiacol, triple carbon–carbon bonded compounds and other compounds [39–42]. For example, M. Miyazaki, et al. [39] prepared Ni-Fe/SiO2 catalyst by co-impregnation for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes. The results show that the formation of Ni-Fe alloy promoted the adsorption of the nitro group and suppressed the hydrogenation of the vinyl group, which increased activity of catalytic reactions and the selectivity of amino-aromatic hydrocarbons. In addition, as for the hydro-deoxidation of guaiacol to cyclohexanol, L. Huang et al. [40] prepared Ni-Fe/MgAlOx catalyst by urea co-precipitation method and found that the Ni-Fe alloy sites promote the aromatic ring hydrogenation activity, meanwhile the basic MgAlOx support can facilitate the removal of methoxy group. The synergistic effect between Ni-Fe alloy and the basic sites of MgAlOx support increases the selectivity of cyclohexanol. For selective hydrogenation of triple carbon-carbon bonded compounds, H.L. Wu et al. [41] prepared Ni1Fe0.15/Al2O3 catalyst by solution combustion synthesis and applied for selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol (BYD) to 1,4-butenediol (BED). It was found that the introduce of Fe regulated the adsorption strength of BYD and H on the surface of the catalyst, favoring the hydrogenation of triple bonds of CC of BYD, thus improving the catalytic hydrogenation activity of BYD and the selectivity of BED. Considering the significant effect of Fe assistant on improving the catalytic hydrogenation performance of nickel, it is worth and meaningful to explore the application of Fe-Ni in the field of selective light alkynes/alkadienes hydrogenation. Herein, a series of bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts with different nickel-iron atomic ratios were prepared by deposition precipitation with urea for selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene, which acts as the probe molecular in the presence of an excess of propylene feedstock due to its fatal poison on the alkenes polymerization catalysts in industry. Remarkable catalytic performance was obtained after adding few amounts of iron into nickel, Ni/Fe atomic ratio 1/0.33 shows above 95% of butenes selectivity at 100% butadiene conversion, with long-term catalytic stability over 200 h of time on stream at 110 °C. XRD analysis indicates that the formation of Ni-Fe intermediates. Importantly, further in-situ analysis (i.e., Pulse CO adsorption, XPS, TPD-MS) reveals that the addition of Fe adatoms disrupt the ensemble of Ni crystallites exposed in the surface of catalysts, and it optimizes the adsorption and reactivity ability of reactants on nickel, offering an enhanced catalytic performance. It indicates that supported Ni-Fe has a high potential for replacing the commercial Pd-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate hexahydrate ((Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, > 98%, Aladdin), Ferrous chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2·4H2O, > 98%, Aladdin), and Titanium dioxide nanoparticles (rutile, 100 nm, Aladdin) were used as reagents, all of which were of analytical grade and required no further purification for use. Deionized water was used in the synthesis and washing process. 2.2 Sample preparation Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts with different nickel-iron atomic ratios were prepared by deposition precipitation with urea (DPU). Specifically, 150 ml of deionized water was added to a double-walled flask, and then two drops of concentrated HNO3 were added to adjust the solution to weak acidity. N2 was bubbled through the solution to remove air. Certain amounts of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and FeCl2·4H2O were weighted and sequentially added to the double-wall reactor, with a fixed 2.5 wt% of Ni loading and varying Ni/Fe atomic ratio of 1:0, 1:0.05, 1:0.1, 1:0.2 and 1:0.33, respectively. After stirring for 10 min under N2 bubbling, urea (urea/metal ions molar ratio ∼ 100:1) was dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water and added to the double-wall reactor. The solution was further bubbled with N2 for 10 min before being sealed. Then the temperature of mixed solution was heated in a water bath to 80 °C, staying for 10 h. After that, the suspension was filtered to collect the solid sample. Then the solid sample was washed in deionized water by filtration for three times, followed by drying at 60 °C for 6 h. Finally, the samples were calcined at 400 °C, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min, for 2 h in a muffle furnace. The calcined samples were ground and sieved to obtain powder samples within a size range of 75–120 mesh for the catalytic analysis, and the rest powder were used for other tests. For further comparison, mono-metal Fe/TiO2 samples with Fe loading of 2.5 wt% and 0.83 wt% were prepared. Moreover, bare TiO2 was treated following the same procedure as that for Ni-Fe/TiO2 samples, then sieved to obtain particles with a size range of 75–120 mesh for the catalytic analysis. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The experimental loadings of Fe and Ni in the samples were evaluated by a Prodigy 7 full-spectrum direct-reading plasma emission spectrometer (ICP). Prior to measurement, the samples were primarily dissolved in acid aqueous for ICP analysis. The reduction behavior of the samples was characterized using the AutoChem1 II 2920 fully automatic temperature programmed chemical adsorption (TPR) instrument. 100 mg of samples was loaded into a U-tube and purged with Ar for 10 min. The analysis was performed following a programmed-temperature: from room temperature to 700 °C, with a heating rate of 5 °C /min, in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). During the analysis, the amount of H2 consumed by sample reduction was detected and recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The crystal structure of the samples was characterized by D8-Advance X-ray electron diffraction analyzer (XRD). The tube voltage and tube current are 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. Cu Kα radiation with a wavelength of 1.54056 Å was used. Prior to testing, the carrier TiO2, Ni/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 samples were reduced at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min) in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). Fe/TiO2 sample was reduced at 550 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min), depending on TPR results, in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). The morphology of the samples was recorded by the Talos F200S high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM), and the accelerating voltage was 200 kV. By statistically analyzing 200 particles from different regions, the particle size distribution of different samples was obtained. In addition, the elemental distribution of the samples was characterized using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Prior to testing, different Ni-Fe/TiO2 powder samples with different Ni-Fe ratios were at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min) in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). The reduced samples were then ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol and deposited on carbon films supported on copper grids. The sample was subjected to pulse CO adsorption (CO-Pulse adsorption) analysis using the same equipment as that of TPR test, which characterized the relative number of active sites on the catalyst. Firstly, the carrier Ni/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 samples were at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min) in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). Fe/TiO2 sample was reduced at 550 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min), depending on TPR results, in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). The reduced samples were then cooled to 50 °C and purged with high-purity He gas to remove excess H2/Ar mixed gas, and the baseline was stabilized before measuring the CO adsorption amount using CO pulse. The electronic environment of nickel and iron on the catalyst surface was characterized using the escalab 250xi in-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (in-situ XPS). The samples were firstly reduced at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min) in 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). The sample was then cooled to room temperature and transferred to the analysis chamber under vacuum condition for testing. The strength of butene adsorption on metallic surface was characterized by conducting butene temperature programmed desorption (Butene-TPD) using the same equipment as that of the TPR test. The sample (120–75 mesh) of 100 mg was loaded into a U-shaped tube and reduced at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min) in the atmosphere of 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). The sample was then cooled to room temperature and purged with Ar for 30 min to remove residual H2/Ar mixed gas. Butene (36 mL/min) was introduced to the reactor for 2 h, reaching saturated adsorption. Afterward, Ar gas (36 mL/min) was used to sweep the system for 1 hour to remove any remaining butene. Finally, temperature programmed desorption (10 °C/min, 700 °C) analysis was carried out in Ar atmosphere (36 mL/min), and the desorbed gas was detected using TCD. The amount of butene adsorption on the surface of sample was further quantified by temperature-programmed butene desorption mass spectrometry (Butene-TPD-MS) using the HPR-40 DEMS instrument. The sample (120–75 mesh) of 100 mg was loaded into a U-shaped tube and reduced at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate: 5 °C/min) in the atmosphere of 10% H2/Ar mixture (36 mL/min). The sample was then cooled to room temperature and purged with He (36 mL/min) for 30 min to remove residual H2/He mixed gas. Butene (36 mL/min) was introduced to adsorb for 2 h, reaching a saturated adsorption. He gas (36 mL/min) was introduced for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed butene. Finally, temperature programmed desorption from RT to 700 °C (heating rate: 10 °C/min) was carried out in helium atmosphere (36 mL/min), and the desorbed gas was quantified by mass spectrometry. 2.4 Catalytic test Selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene in propylene-rich stream was carried out in a U-shaped quartz fix-bed reactor. 20 mg of Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalyst and 80 mg of TiO2 dispersant were evenly mixed and filled into a U-shaped reactor. The mixture was pre-reduced at 450 °C (5 °C/min) for 1 h in 36 mL/min of 10% H2/He mixture gas. After cooling down to room temperature, a gas mixture of 3.8 vol% H2, 3.2 vol% propylene and 0.12 vol% butadiene in helium (i.e., propylene/butadiene vol ratio ∼26:1, simulating the industrial process) was introduced into the reactor at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 11,426 h − 1. The gas flows were controlled by mass flow controllers. The temperature-programmed reaction was performed in the temperature range from 30 °C to 120 °C, with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. The composition of outlet gas was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) every 15 mins (i.e., every 15 °C). The temperature of the chromatography column was 75 °C, and the flame ionization detector (FID) temperature was 220 °C. Butadiene conversion C% (1) and butenes selectivity S% (2) are calculated as follows: (1) C % = 100 % × ( 1 − N B u t a d i e n e o u t N B u t a d i e n e i n ) (2) S % = 100 % × N B u t e n e s o u t N B u t e n e s o u t + N B u t a n e o u t Here, NButadiene in represents the initial amount of butadiene, and NButadiene out represents the amount of butadiene in outlet gas. NButenes out represents the amount of butene in the products (e.g., 1-butene, trans-2-butene and cis-2-butene), and NButanes out represents the amount of butane in the products. The catalytic activity (3) is calculated as follows: (3) A c t i v i t y ( m o l · S − 1 · g m e t a l − 1 ) = 100 % × ( B u t a d i e n e c o n . ) p p m · Q m c a t a l + w t % m e t a l × P R · T Here, (Butadienecon.)ppm represents the concentration of butadiene converted to butene and butane; Q is the flow rate of the gas mixture; P/RT =V (24 mol/L). The metal dispersion (4) is calculated as follows: (4) D M = m × Q 1000 × ( W × P / M ) Here, DM represents the degree of metal dispersion; Q is the total amount of species adsorbed by the adsorbent, expressed in mmol; m is the stoichiometric coefficient of metal atoms and adsorbate gas, indicating that an adsorbate gas is adsorbed by m metal atoms; W is the total mass of catalyst (g), expressed in g; P is the mass fraction of metal in the catalyst; M is the molar mass of the metal, expressed in g/mol. The conversion frequency (TOF) (5) is calculated as follows: (5) T O F ( s − 1 ) = A c t i v i t y · M m e t a l D i s p e r s i o n Among them, Activity is catalyst activity, Mmetal is the molar mass of the metal, and Dispersion is metal dispersion. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Basic analysis of Ni-Fe/TiO2 The composition of the calcined Fe-Ni/TiO2 samples was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), with the theoretical and experimental metal loadings summarized in Table 1 . Nominally, the Ni loading in all samples was controlled as constant at 2.5 wt%, with varying Fe loading from 0.12 wt%, 0.25 wt%, 0.5 wt% to 0.82 wt% for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, respectively. Experimentally, the Ni loadings in all samples are slightly lower than that of nominal value (2.5 wt%), while the loadings of Fe are close to the nominal ones. Considering the fact that the synthesis method of co-deposition-precipitation with urea mainly based on the decomposition of urea for OH− releasing, which increases the pH of synthesis solution and favors metal ions deposition onto TiO2 surface. The difference in metal loadings between nominal and experimental values can be attributed to the solubility of iron oxides (i.e., Ksp Fe(OH)2 = 8 × 10−16, Ksp Fe(OH)3 = 4 × 10−38), which are much lower than that of Ni(OH)2 (i.e., Ksp Ni(OH)2 = 2 × 10−15). Nevertheless, the obtained bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 samples have similar Ni loading, with expected Ni/Fe atomic ratios for further study. The reduction behavior of calcined Ni-Fe/TiO2 samples was evaluated by temperature program reduction (TPR) under H2 atmosphere in Fig. 1 . It shows that TiO2 carrier has no observed H2 consumption peak below 700 °C, indicating a negligible reduction in the testing temperature range. As for mono-metal Ni/TiO2, a broad H2 consumption peak appears in the temperature range of 290 ∼ 450 °C, which corresponds to the reduction of nickel oxide on the TiO2 support [43]. After the addition of iron, Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2 shows a H2 consumption peak at 300 ∼ 450 °C, with a center at around 390 °C. Moreover, with an increase of Fe loading, the H2 consumption peak gradually shifts to lower temperature, which centers at 385 °C, 382 °C, 376 °C and 372 °C for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, respectively. Interestingly, mono-metal Fe/TiO2 starts to be reduced at 450 C, with a H2 consumption peak by iron oxides reduction staying in 450 ∼ 550 °C [44], which is much higher than that of Ni/TiO2 and Ni-Fe/TiO2. It indicates that the addition of Fe could promote the reducibility of supported nickel species, meanwhile, the existed Ni also accelerate the reduction of iron compounds. It has been reported [45] that the decrease in the reduction temperature of iron and nickel oxides was mainly attributed to the interaction between Ni and Fe. Specifically, metallic Ni has high activity for H2 dissociation, the formed hydrogen atom intermediates on Ni could accelerates the reduction of iron oxide [46,47]. Moreover, the introduction of appropriate Fe in Ni, with the formation of Ni-Fe-O compound (e.g., NiFe2O4), weakens the interaction between nickel and the carrier, promoting the reduction of nickel oxide [48]. Therefore, based on the TPR analysis, reduction temperature of 450 °C for 1 h was selected to reduce Ni-Fe/TiO2 for the later catalytic test. The metallic phase in Ni-Fe/TiO2 samples after reduction at 450 °C for 1 h was evaluated by x-ray diffraction (XRD), with 2-theta range in 40 ∼ 47.5° presented in Fig. 2 . Comparison with bare TiO2, a diffraction peak at 2θ ∼ 44.51° appears in the Ni/TiO2 sample in Fig. 2(a). It belongs to the (1 1 1) facet of metallic Ni (JCPDS Card 04–0850), which has a crystal structure of face-centered cubic. Moreover, a reference of Fe/TiO2 sample after reduction at 550 °C for 1 h was also checked by XRD, which shows a diffraction peak at 44.67°, corresponding to the (1 1 0) crystal plane of metallic Fe (i.e., body-centered cubic, JCPDS Card 99–0064). As for bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts, with an increase of Fe loading from 0 to 0.82 wt%, the characteristic diffraction peak of the Ni(1 1 1) facet at ∼44.51° gradually shifts to 44.44°, 44.39°, 44.27° for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2, respectively [49,50]. It finally reaches at 44.12° for Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, corresponding to a bimetallic Ni3Fe alloy phase (JCPD Card 65–3244). Further analysis on the lattice parameter of metallic Ni and bimetallic Ni3Fe alloy in Fig. 2(b), it reveals that the peak shifts toward a small value of 2-theta is mainly due to the incorporation of Fe atoms into the Ni lattice, offering an increase in the interplanar distance owing to the larger atomic radius of Fe (rFe = 1.26 Å) than that of Ni (rNi = 1.24 Å) [51]. More importantly, the replacement of Ni by Fe atoms changes the coordination environment of Ni atom in lattice, offering a decrease in the number of adjacent Ni atom. Meanwhile, it enlarges the distance between adjacent Ni atoms, with the distance increasing from 2.49 Å to 2.51 Å for the Fe loading at 0 and 0.82 wt%, respectively (as shown in the schematic diagram in Fig. 2b). The results show that the introduction of Fe leads to the formation of Ni-Fe intermetallic compounds between nickel and iron, and it further alters the geometric property of active Ni sites. Fig. 3 (a-e) includes the TEM morphologies and the particle size distribution of Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts with different Ni/Fe atomic ratios. As shown in Fig. 3(a-e), the metallic particles in Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts are highly dispersed on the surface of the TiO2 carrier, with uniform particle sizes. Specifically, the average particle size of Ni in mono-metal Ni/TiO2 catalysts was 3.92 nm. With an increase of Fe loading from 0.12 wt% to 0.82 wt%, the average particle size gradually increased from 3.92 nm to 3.88 nm, 4.48 nm, 5.56 nm and 6.32 nm for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, respectively [31]. To obtain the element distribution behavior of Ni and Fe over the surface of bimetallic Fe-Ni nanoparticle, TEM-EDS characterization was performed, using Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 as a probe sample in Fig. 3(f-i). In detail, the linear EDS scanning on a metallic nanoparticle in the reduced Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 was exhibited in Fig. 3(f), and the illustration displays the element distribution of Ni and Fe atoms following the black arrow on the surface of particle, which is highlighted in the orange dashed circle. The linear EDS scanning of a single particle reveals that Ni and Fe are uniformly distributed on the particle. Moreover, the EDS mapping on metallic particles shows that the metallic particles are mainly composed by Ni and Fe, with atomic ratio of 76:24, indicating the formation of a Ni-Fe intermetallic compound (e.g., Ni3Fe alloy). It is consistent with XRD results. Fig. 3(g-i) shows the Fe and Ni element distribution maps obtained from the EDS mapping in Fig. 3(f), which indicate that Ni and Fe elements are uniformly distributed on the particle surface. This suggests that Ni and Fe form a fundamentally uniform alloy structure. Further quantification on the amount of exposed Ni active site in Ni-Fe/TiO2 was performed by CO-Pulse adsorption analysis after in-situ reduction in H2 at 450 °C for 1 h in Fig. 4 . It illustrates the evolution of CO cumulative adsorption values as a function of CO pulse cycle for Ni-Fe/TiO2 with different Ni/Fe atomic ratios. It can be found that CO has low adsorption on mono-metal 2.5 wt% Fe/TiO2, with the amount of CO below 1.0 μmol/g. Contrarily, as for mono-metal Ni/TiO2, it shows a highest CO adsorption (i.e., 6.7 μmol/g), indicating that CO preferably adsorbs on Ni surface. With an increase of Fe loading in Ni-Fe/TiO2, the amount of CO adsorption decreases to 6.2 μmol/g, 6.0 μmol/g, 2.8 μmol/g and 1.8 μmol/g for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, respectively. The decrease of CO adsorption indicates that the introduction of Fe atoms dilutes the Ni atoms on the surface of intermediate Ni-Fe compounds, affecting the micro-environment of supported Ni by reducing the number of Ni active sites on the surface of catalyst [44,52]. The electronic interaction between metallic Ni and Fe was analyzed by an in-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (In-situ XPS) at 450 °C in H2 atmosphere (Fig. 5 ). In Ni/TiO2, the binding energy of 852.88 eV corresponds to the zero-valent Ni metal, while the binding energy of 855.98 eV and 861.80 eV are attributed to Ni 2p3/2 of Ni2+ and its satellite peaks, respectively [31,53,52]. The residual Ni2+ after reduction could be attributed to the incomplete reduction of the sample [54]. After the introduction of Fe, forming intermediate Ni-Fe compounds, the Ni 2p3/2 of Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 shifts to a low binding energy of 852.36 eV. This type of shift indicates an increase in the electron density of Ni as the electronegativity of Ni is 1.9, which is higher than that of Fe (i.e., 1.8). Therefore, the introduction of Fe promotes the electron transfer from Fe to Ni, altering the electron cloud density of Ni [48,55,56]. 3.2 Characterization of butene desorption property Considering the fact that butenes are expected products from selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene. The adsorption strength between butenes and catalytic surface plays a key role on deciding the productivity of butenes during hydrogenation reaction [57]. Thus, clarification of the effect of Fe on the butenes adsorption behavior over Ni active site was important, and it was analyzed by 1-butene temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) coupled with either thermal conductor detector (TCD) or mass spectrometry (MS) in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6(a) displays the butene-TPD-TCD curves of TiO2 support and Ni-Fe/TiO2 with different nickel-iron ratios after in-situ reduction at 450 °C for 1 h. Firstly, the blank TiO2 sample exhibits a 1-butene (i.e., a main product of butadiene semi-hydrogenation) desorption peak at ∼ 175 °C, which corresponds to the weak adsorption of butene on the carrier TiO2 [37]. After loading 2.5 wt% of Ni (i.e., Ni/TiO2), in addition to the peak at 175 °C, two desorption peaks at 335 °C and 540 °C were observed, indicating the presence of two different types of 1-butene adsorption over Ni surface. The desorption peak at low temperature (i.e., 335 °C) was attributed to the desorption of π-adsorbed butene, and the desorption peak at high temperature (i.e., 540 °C) was attributed to the desorption of di-σ-adsorbed butene [58]. As a reference, Fe/TiO2 sample exhibits a weak desorption peak at 335 °C, which corresponds to the small amount of π-adsorbed butene, with relatively weak adsorption strength. After addition of Fe into Ni, it was found that the intensity of the desorption peak of di-σ-adsorbed butene decreases with an increase of Fe loading. More importantly, the desorption temperature of di-σ-adsorbed butene also shifts towards low temperature, i.e., with 540 °C, 524 °C and 510 °C for Ni/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 are, respectively. While, interestingly, all bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 shows similar peak area of π-adsorbed butene at around 335 °C, revealing that the addition of Fe has no effect on the π-adsorbed butene over Ni surface. Therefore, the results suggest that the introduction of Fe weakens the adsorption of di-σ-adsorption butene on bimetallic Ni-Fe surface. It might be due to the influence of Fe on the geometric structure and electronic properties of Ni in Fig. 2-5 [59,60]. In addition, the influence of Fe on the adsorption capacity of Ni-based catalysts for butene was further checked by in-situ temperature-programmed butene desorption coupled with Butene-TPD-MS, using Ni/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 as probe samples in Fig. 6(b), with detailed MS spectra in the molecular weight rang of 20 to 60 presented in Fig. S1. With the temperature increasing from 30 °C to 700 °C, the desorption of 1-butene was recorded by analysis of the hydrocarbon species with molecular weight of 44, which corresponds to the fragments of 1-butene. It shows that Ni/TiO2 catalyst exhibits two desorption peaks for butene at 308 °C and 448 °C, which highly agrees with the results of Butene-TPD-TCD test in Fig. 6(a). However, after introducing small amount of Fe (i.e., Ni/Fe atomic ratio 1:0.33), it obtained only one desorption peak at low temperature (i.e., 302 °C), corresponding to weakly adsorbed π-adsorption butene. Importantly, no butene desorption peaks were detected at high temperature (e.g., above 440 °C), revealing that the addition of Fe weakened the strongly adsorbed butene of di-σ-adsorption mode. This observation highly agrees with the above results in Fig. 6(a). Firstly, adjacent Ni sites are conducive to the formation of strongly adsorbed di-σ-adsorption butene, while the introduction of Fe sharply reduces the number of adjacent Ni sites, thereby inhibiting the formation of di-σ-adsorption butene. Secondly, the Electron transfer from Fe to Ni increases the electron density of Ni, reduces the adsorption performance of Ni, and thus weakens the adsorption of butene [56]. Moreover, Similar unsaturated metal sites for molecular selective adsorption was also observed in microporous metal–organic frameworks [61]. 3.3 Selective butadiene hydrogenation performance The catalytic performance for butadiene selective hydrogenation in the presence of an excess of propylene (Vpropylene:Vbutadiene ∼26:1) on various Ni-Fe/TiO2 as a function of temperature was evaluated and summarized in Fig. 7 . As for the reference of mono-metal Fe/TiO2, Fig. 7(a) shows that it has a relative low activity to butadiene hydrogenation, with butadiene conversion below 2% in the reaction temperature range (i.e., 30∼110 °C). Moreover, the butadiene conversion of mono-metal Ni/TiO2 gradually climbed from below 2% at 30 °C to 10% at 75 °C, followed by a rapid increase to 100% at 100 °C. After introducing small amount of Fe, as for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, the butadiene conversion stayed below 30% at 90 °C, and it is much lower than that of mono-metal Ni catalyst (e.g., 45% at 90 °C). While they have same 100% butadiene conversion temperature (T100%) at 100 °C. With an increase of Fe loading, the T100% increased from 100 °C to 105 °C and 110 °C for Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, respectively, indicating a decrease of catalytic activity by adding Fe assistant. Furthermore, an additional catalytic test was also performed on a physical mixture of mono-metal Fe/TiO2 and mono-metal Ni/TiO2 (i.e., a physical mixture of 2.5 wt% of Ni/TiO2 and 0.82 wt% of Fe/TiO2 for reaching a Ni/Fe atomic ratio 1:0.33), which offers a same butadiene conversion behavior under different temperature as that of mono-metal Ni/TiO2 catalyst. It reveals that Ni, instead of Fe, is the main catalytic active site among butadiene selective hydrogenation. In addition, the catalytic activity of all Ni-Fe/TiO2 samples at 75 °C was calculated as turnover frequency (i.e., TOF) and presented in Fig. 7(b). The TOF values of Ni/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 catalysts are 5.10 s − 1, 4.78 s − 1, 4.5 s − 1, 4.47 s − 1 and 4.20 s − 1, respectively. From the TOF values of the catalysts with different Ni-Fe ratios, mono-metal Ni/TiO2 has a highest TOF, showing a highest catalytic activity towards butadiene. With the addition of Fe, the TOF value of the bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts slightly decreases. The difference in TOF values between different Ni-Fe ratio bimetallic catalysts is not significant. These results indicate that the introduction of an appropriate amount of Fe has limited effect on the catalyst activity. Moreover, combined with the XRD data in Fig. 2 and CO-pulse adsorption analysis in Fig. 4, alloying Ni with Fe leads to that a partial Ni atom on the surface of metallic particle are replaced by Fe. Since Ni is the catalytic active site in the Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts, thus alloying Fe with Ni brings a decrease in the amount of catalytic active Ni center for hydrogenation reaction, resulting in a decrease in the observed catalytic activity. The catalytic selectivity to alkenes (butenes and propylene) of Ni-Fe/TiO2 during butadiene selective hydrogenation in the presence of an excess of propylene at different temperatures were compared in Fig. 7(c) and (d). In Fig. 7(c), butenes selectivity as a function of reaction temperature for Ni-Fe/TiO2 was included. Specifically, mono-metal Ni/TiO2 catalyst has high butenes selectivity at low reaction temperature (e.g., 94.28% of butenes selectivity at 67.3% of butadiene conversion at 95 °C), unfortunately, the butenes selectivity dramatically dropped to below 49.14% once butadiene conversion reaches to 100%. However, after alloying Ni with Fe, the butenes selectivity of bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 was significantly improved, with butenes selectivity staying at 50.05%, 52.90%, 84.52%, and 95.12% for Ni1Fe0.05/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.1/TiO2, Ni1Fe0.2/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 at the T100%, respectively. In addition, as a reference, the physical mixture of mono-metal Fe/TiO2 and mono-metal Ni/TiO2, with Ni/Fe atomic ratio 1:0.33, shows butenes selectivity at ∼50%, which is similar as that of monometallic Ni catalyst. It indicates that alloying Fe with Ni, with the formation of Ni-Fe intermetallic compounds, can efficiently enhance the butenes selectivity of Ni site. In addition to butenes selectivity, the catalytic selectivity to propylene is also a vital point in this selective hydrogenation reaction. Fig. 7(d) displays the preservation percentage of propylene in feedstocks at 100% conversion of 1,3-butadiene. Mono metallic Ni/TiO2 shows only 51.8% at 100% conversion of 1,3-butadiene, indicating a waste of 48.2% carbon resources. However, the introduction of Fe largely enhances the percentage of propylene in outlet gas. Specially, it reaches to 99.99% for Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 catalyst, which has a great significance for the industrial application for removing alkynes/alkadienes impurities in alkenes feedstocks. Based on the above analysis in Fig. 2-4, it indicates that the introduction of Fe reduced the number of adjacent Ni sites and increased the distance between adjacent Ni atoms, which inhibits the formation of strongly adsorbed di-σ-adsorption butene. In addition, in-situ XPS verifies that the charge transfer from Fe to Ni, offering an electronic-rich surface of Ni, thereby reducing the adsorption strength of butenes [54]. Therefore, the addition of Fe significantly enhanced the catalytic selectivity to alkenes of Ni catalysts, especially at condition of high butadiene conversion (i.e., 100% of 1,3-butadiene conversion). Superior stability is one the most important parameters for catalyst in industrial application. Fig. 8 illustrates the evolution of butadiene conversion, butene selectivity and propane formation as a function of reaction time for both mono-metal Ni/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2, with an initial butadiene conversion at 99.8%. It can be found that the butadiene conversion of mono-metal Ni/TiO2 catalyst decrease from 99.8% to below 80.12% after 92 h of time on stream in Fig. 8(a). However, an excellent catalytic stability was obtained for Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 catalyst, which shows a butadiene conversion stays as a constant at above 99% over 150 h of the reaction and stays at above 94% even after 200 h of catalytic reaction. Importantly, the butenes selectivity of Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 keeps as a constant at above 95% during the 200 h of stability test. It is superior to that of mono-metal Ni/TiO2, which has only around 50% at beginning and strongly depends on the butadiene conversion. Thus, the introduced Fe in Ni proposed a diluted Ni distribution over metallic Ni surface, with the enlarged distance between two Ni atoms from 2.49 Å to 2.51 Å, offering high steric effect for oligomerization of adsorbed hydrocarbons, contributing to an enhanced catalytic stability (i.e., thermal-gravity analysis on the samples after stability test in Fig. S2 reveals the oligomers formation on mono-metal Ni/TiO2 and Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2 are 0.09 mg/h and 0.04 mg/h, respectively). Further XRD analysis on the Ni-Fe/TiO2 after stability test was presented in Fig. S3, which shows similar characteristic peaks between the fresh-reduced sample and the sample after catalytic test, indicating a high structural integrity during catalytic reaction at relatively low temperature (e.g., ∼110 °C for Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2). Significantly, in Fig. 8b, comparison with commercial Pd/Al2O3 catalyst (10 wt% of Pd), which has been evaluated under the similar condition and shows butadiene conversion decrease from 100% to below 5% after 105 h of time on stream, with alkenes selectivity increasing from 10% to 90% and propane formation decreased from 100% to 3% [62], our developed bimetallic Ni-Fe catalyst (e.g., Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2) shows high potential for further industrial application. In addition, further comparison with the previous studies on Pd-based catalysts in selective alkynes and alkadienes hydrogenation was summarized in Table S1, it can be found that the developed bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts show great advantages, especially in the aspect of catalytic alkenes selectivity (i.e., >95%) and long-term stability (i.e., 200 h). To make a clarification of the Fe-Ni alloying effect on enhancing the catalytic performance of Ni in butadiene selective hydrogenation, a schematic diagram was summarized in Fig. 9 . Specifically, as for heterogenous hydrogenation on mono-metallic Ni/TiO2, butadiene was firstly adsorbed on Ni surface. It further hydrogenates with the hydrogen atom intermediates, which are mainly obtained by H2 dissociation, with the formation of butenes as the semi-hydrogenation product. Since butenes are strongly adsorbed on Ni surface (i.e., di-σ-adsorption with high desorption temperature in Fig. 6), butadiene and butenes are easily further hydrogenated, with butane as the main product (shown in Fig. 7) [63]. However, after introduction of Fe into Ni crystal (e.g., intermetallic Ni-Fe compounds), partial Ni active sites were replaced by Fe atoms, causing a high dispersion of active Ni sites and electron transferring from Fe to Ni. They weaken the adsorption of butenes (e.g., di-σ-adsorption in Fig. 6) on catalytic surface, offering a high catalytic selectivity to butenes [64]. Furthermore, the diluted Ni active sites on bimetallic nanoparticle surface, with an enlarged distance between adjacent Ni atoms, largely restricts oligomerization of adsorbed hydrocarbons, offering a superior stability. 4 Conclusion In this study, non-noble bimetallic nickel-iron catalysts synthesized by deposition-precipitation with urea were explored as a substitute for palladium-based catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene in the presence of an excess of propylene. It was found that, comparison with commercial Pd/Al2O3 catalyst and monometallic Ni/TiO2, bimetallic Ni-Fe catalysts (e.g., Ni1Fe0.33/TiO2) show a superior catalytic performance, with above 95% of butenes selectivity at 94% of butadiene conversion for over 200 h of time on stream. Importantly, in-situ analysis reveals that the dispersion of Ni sites and the electronic transfer from Fe to Ni largely promotes the desorption of butenes products by reducing the amount of strongly adsorbed butenes in di-σ-adsorption mode, offering a better alkenes selectivity than that of monometallic Ni. Furthermore, the alloying effect from the Ni-Fe intermetallic compounds formation offers a diluted Ni active sites on bimetallic nanoparticle surface, with an enlarged distance between adjacent Ni atoms. It also largely restricts oligomerization of adsorbed hydrocarbons, offering a superior stability. These findings provide valuable insights for the rational design of economically efficient Ni-based catalysts for selective hydrogenation of low-carbon olefins. coredata.dc:description: Nickel is a promising Pd alternative candidate for selective alkynes/alkadienes hydrogenation owing to its high catalytic activity and cheap price, however, with fatal restrictions of low alkenes selectivity and inferior stability caused by its strong olefin adsorption and the cleavage of carbon-carbon bond. Herein, controlled amounts of iron were introduced into nickel as catalytic assistant by deposition-precipitation with urea on TiO2 support. Using 1,3-butadiene in an excess of propylene to simulate the industrial process, the additional Fe shows a significant enhancement to the catalytic performance of Ni, i.e., Ni-Fe/TiO2 with Ni/Fe atomic ratio 1:0.33 shows >94% of 1,3-butadiene conversion and >95% of alkenes selectivity after above 200 h of time on stream, superior to that of commercial Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. Further in-situ analysis reveals that the alloying effect from the formation of Ni-rich Ni-Fe intermetallic compound (e.g., Ni3Fe alloy) enlarges the distance between two Ni active sites and enriches the electronic density of Ni sites, resulting in a weak adsorption of butenes products for offering such excellent catalytic performance. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first in-depth exploration on supported Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrogenation of light alkynes/alkadienes. It shows a high potential for replacing the commercial Pd-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Alloying effect enhanced bimetallic Ni-Fe/TiO2 catalysts for selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene in the presence of an excess of propylene
